importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous longest government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, and lasted 35 days until January 25, 2019.
The end date of the previous longest government shutdown, marking the conclusion of a 35-day closure that set a historical record.
The date of the article's publication, indicating the ongoing status of the current government shutdown in October 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This 35-day period represents the longest federal government shutdown in U.S. history, with significant economic and societal consequences.
The current government shutdown is ongoing as of October 21, 2025, with no funding agreement in place for the 12 appropriations bills needed to reopen the government.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown lasted 35 days, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, making it the longest in history.
The 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office.
During the 2018 shutdown, approximately 800,000 federal employees were affected, with about 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from work but unpaid.
The current shutdown is a full government shutdown because Congress has not passed any of the 12 required appropriations bills to fund federal operations.
A partial shutdown in 1976 marked the first federal government shutdown, with federal agencies instructed to stop operations during funding lapses.
Since 1990, there have been six government shutdowns, indicating a decline in frequency but increasing political polarization making resolution difficult.
The current Congress faces challenges due to a narrow House majority and lack of 60 votes in the Senate to end a filibuster, making negotiations difficult in the final hours.
Furloughed and exempt employees receive backpay when agencies reopen after funding is approved.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government remains shut down in October 2025 due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This marks a full government shutdown, in contrast to the 2018 partial shutdown that lasted 35 days — the longest in history — and cost the economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. The 2018 shutdown affected approximately 800,000 employees, with 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from work. Since 1990, there have been six shutdowns, with increasing political polarization and procedural obstacles like the Senate filibuster making resolution difficult. The current situation is further complicated by a narrow House majority and lack of bipartisan consensus, highlighting ongoing challenges in U.S. legislative funding processes.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
